text: Lasers are being used to create an ultra-fast network that can carry data at speeds of up to 1Tbps (terabit per second).
The technology, which is being trialled in the UK, could eventually be used to connect data centres and other high-speed networks.
The system uses a technique called "mode division multiplexing" to encode data onto different beams of light.
This means that multiple streams of data can be sent down a single fibre optic cable at the same time.
The trial, which is being conducted by BT and the University of Southampton, is using a prototype system that can achieve speeds of up to 1Tbps.
This is around 100 times faster than the current fastest broadband speeds available in the UK.
The system is based on a technology called "optical time domain multiplexing" (OTDM), which is already used in some commercial systems.
However, the BT/Southampton system is the first to use mode division multiplexing, which allows data to be encoded onto different beams of light.
This means that multiple streams of data can be sent down a single fibre optic cable at the same time.
